https://prez.dev/description.@value: Compilation of terms that describe the classification of alteration in a rock, with a focus on hydrothermal processes (i.e. mineralogical, chemical and textural changes resulting from the interaction of hot aqueous fluids with the rocks through which they circulate, under evolving physico-chemical conditions), and excluding weathering, mineralization and direct metamorphic or magmatic processes. Classification is based on the identification of the most important alteration mineral, the distinctive mineral assemblage, or the chemical changes that have occurred during alteration. Definitions are largely from Pirajno (2009), the Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et.al., 2011), Thompson et al. (1996), and Wikipedia.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Alteration that introduces clay minerals including kaolinite, smectite and illite as a replacement of plagioclase and amphibole due to intense H+ metasomatism and acid leaching, at temperatures between 100째 and 300째C.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition adapted from Glossary of Geology (5th edition revised, Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Alteration that introduces clay minerals including kaolinite, smectite and illite as a replacement of plagioclase and amphibole due to intense H+ metasomatism and acid leaching, at temperatures between 100째 and 300째C.

A type of argillic alteration defined by intensive acid attack and more or less complete leaching of the alkali cations with complete destruction of the feldspars and mafic silicate phases, resulting in an assemblage of dickite, kaolinite, pyrophillite, baryte, alunite and diaspore. In addition, sulfides, topaz, tourmaline and a range of amorphous clays may be present. Found in porphyry systems, in the inner zone of hydrothermal base and precious metal-bearing veins, and most typically in high-sulfur hydrothermal systems.

A type of argilllic alteration defined by the presence of montmorillonite, illite, chlorite, kaolin group clays (kaolinite, dickite, halloysite, allophane) and minor sericite. K-feldspar may remain unaltered, and K, Ca, Mg and Na may not entirely leach out. Precursor textures are usually preserved.
